goals.question: What is the distribution of volcano elevation?
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the range of elevation values and how they are distributed. It can also help us identify any outliers or unusual patterns in the data.

goals.question: What is the relationship between volcano elevation and type?
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand if there is a significant difference in elevation between different types of volcanoes. It can also help us identify any outliers or unusual patterns in the data.

goals.question: What is the distribution of volcano type?
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the frequency of different types of volcanoes in the dataset. It can also help us identify any rare or unusual types of volcanoes.

goals.question: What is the relationship between volcano type and region?
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the distribution of different types of volcanoes across different regions. It can also help us identify any regions that have a higher concentration of a particular type of volcano.

goals.question: What is the distribution of volcano last eruption year?
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the range of last known eruption years and how they are distributed. It can also help us identify any unusual patterns or gaps in the data.

code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    plt.hist(data['Elevation'], bins=20, color='blue', alpha=0.7, label='Elevation')
    plt.axvline(data['Elevation'].median(), color='red', linestyle='dashed', linewidth=2, label=f"Median: {data['Elevation'].median():.2f}")
    plt.xlabel('Elevation')
    plt.ylabel('Frequency')
    plt.title('What is the distribution of volcano elevation?', wrap=True)
    plt.legend()
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
    sns.boxplot(x='Type', y='Elevation', data=data, palette='Set2')
    plt.title('What is the relationship between volcano elevation and type?', wrap=True)
    plt.xlabel('Type')
    plt.ylabel('Elevation')
    plt.xticks(rotation=45)
    plt.legend(title='Volcano Types', loc='upper right')
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    # Count the frequency of each volcano type
    type_counts = data['Type'].value_counts()

    # Create a bar chart of volcano types
    plt.bar(type_counts.index, type_counts.values)

    # Set the chart title and labels
    plt.title('What is the distribution of volcano type?')
    plt.xlabel('Volcano Type')
    plt.ylabel('Frequency')

    # Rotate x-axis labels for better readability
    plt.xticks(rotation=45)

    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data_grouped = data.groupby(['Region', 'Type']).size().unstack(fill_value=0)
    data_grouped.plot(kind='bar', stacked=True, figsize=(12, 6))
    
    plt.title("What is the relationship between volcano type and region?", wrap=True)
    plt.xlabel("Region")
    plt.ylabel("Number of Volcanoes")
    plt.xticks(rotation=45)
    plt.legend(title="Volcano Type", loc="upper right")
    
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['Last Known Eruption Year'] = pd.to_datetime(data['Last Known Eruption Year'], errors='coerce')
    data = data[pd.notna(data['Last Known Eruption Year'])]
    data['Last Known Eruption Year'] = data['Last Known Eruption Year'].dt.year

    plt.hist(data['Last Known Eruption Year'], bins=30, color='blue', alpha=0.7, label='Last Eruption Year')
    plt.xlabel('Last Known Eruption Year')
    plt.ylabel('Frequency')
    plt.title('What is the distribution of volcano last eruption year?', wrap=True)
    plt.legend()
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)
